newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates down, spots mostly up.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates down, spots mostly up.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed down across the board on Thursday on a technical correction after sharp rises on Wednesday, traders said.
The annual rate for the most actively traded seven-day contract plunged to 10.85 percent from 18.00 percent on Wednesday.
Total turnover of the six-contract market fell sharply to 2.53 million lots from 5.61 million lots.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
The rates experienced a rational technical correction after Wednesday's sharp rises, traders said.

"Both volume and rates fell today when fund demand fell sharply after yesterday's big new issue on the Shanghai bourse," said one trader, referring to Sanxia Shuili, an electricity company who shares debut on Wednesday.
Traders said falls on the domestic A share markets were another factor exerting downward pressure, especially on the early-maturing contracts.

The volume of a new A share issue on the Shenzhen stock exchange, Shandong Xinhua Zhiyao -- which is also listed as an H share in Hong Kong -- was too small to support Wednesday's repo rates, other traders said.
Traders said they expected the rates to fall further, though slightly, on Friday on a lack of fresh market-moving factors.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mostly up on Thursday on a technical rebound after falls in past few days, traders said.
The most actively traded two-year bond that matures in January 1999 rose to 87.20 yuan from 86.79 yuan.
Combined volume of the eight-contract market rose slightly to 681,650 lots from 657,112 lots.
Traders said Thursday's rises were only a technical rebound because the market volume did not increasing accordingly.
As a result, they said, rates should consolidate around current levels in the short term.
